./.title: Installation
./.body:
Rinobot 







Rinobot is an app to automatic research data processing.It syncs everything in your folders with rinocloud. It
also lets you hook in packages to automatically process your data when it
appears in the folder.Currently you'll need a Rinocloud account to use
Rinobot. This is for verification, and so that you can sync with your
Rinocloud account. If your using the on-site version of Rinocloud, or don't want
to put your data in the cloud; thats no problem.Follow the installation instructions below and then head to the Getting started
guide.Installing RinobotDownload the installer below for windows or mac. You do not need
administrator privileges to install Rinobot, it installs into the local user
account.Installer for Windows

Installer for Mac


Open the downloaded file and allow Rinobot to set itself up!
When prompted, log in using your Rinocloud account.
(Optional) Plugins: Install the Anaconda python framework to use the library
of Rinobot plugins for automatically processing, plotting and converting data on
the fly.[Anaconda python downloads](https://www.continuum.io/downloads Install the distribution for python3.5.


You're all set! Head over to the Getting started
guide so start using Rinobot.Using Rinobot to automatically convert and plot incoming data.

introduction/getting_started.html.title: Getting started with Rinobot
introduction/getting_started.html.body:
Getting startedHeres everything you need to get Rinobot working in a few minutes.Download and install Rinobot so that Rinobot can start automatically processing
and syncing your data.
Choose a folder on your computer that Rinobot will monitor for data and sync with Rinocloud.
Install some plugins and choose a set of tasks for Rinobot to do on your data.
Example: automatically convert and plot incoming data.



Hows its done.Search and install the plugins parse-spc and interactive-line-plot in the 'Plugins' section of Rinobot.

Choose the folder you want to monitor.

Setup the tasks on the folder by clicking the 'Settings' button under the folder name. Here we setup the parser and the plotter to process the incoming data, and then we upload to Rinocloud.
Press 'Start' and Rinobot will start monitoring the folder.When Rinobot notices the appearance of a .spc file it automatically parses it and outputs the spectrum numbers to a .txt file, and it outputs the experimental metadata to a .yaml file.

Then Rinobot picks up the .txt file and automatically plots it; outputting an interactive plot into a .html file, using other plugins its easy to export to many image file formats.

Rinobot then uploads all the data to Rinocloud, attaching the metadata to the files to make the easy to search for later.


More informationDefining tasks for Rinobot to run

Installing plugins

plugins/.title: Plugins
plugins/.body:
IntroductionInstalling a package

Creating a package

plugins/installing_a_plugin.html.title: Installing a plugin
plugins/installing_a_plugin.html.body:
Installing a pluginPlugins make it easy to extend the functionality of Rinobot, and we are making new plugins every day.
We are very responsive to plugin requests, so if you want a plugin made please email plugins@rinocloud.com.Go to the 'Plugins' section of Rinobot, select a plugin that you want to use, and click install.

plugins/creating_a_plugin.html.title: Creating a plugin
plugins/creating_a_plugin.html.body:
Creating a Rinobot pluginThere is a prototype plugin repository available where most of the configuration and setup is already done for you; just download it and start editing your code.Rinobot Plugin PrototypeInstallationDownload the prototype repository
or clone it git clone https://github.com/rinocloud/rinobot-plugin-prototype.git
First you will need python3 installed, we recommend the Anaconda Python 3
distribution because its what we require Rinobot users to install, it contains a
large number of useful scientific libraries like numpy, scipy and matplotlib by
default.Anaconda Python install Python 3

List of default packages

ConfigurationYou will need to install node.js and npm, and make an NPM account in order to publish your plugin
to the npm package directory.Node & NPM installation

Create an npm account

The package.json fileThis is the file which holds all the configuration for your rinobot pluginInside the package.json you will need to:prefix the package name with rinobot-plugin-
include the keyword rinobot
Most of this is done for you already in the prototype repo, but you'll need to change
the package name and user, and version.Programming your pluginTo make your own plugin just start editing the index.py file in python. You
can import all the default packages installed by
Anaconda.Also its good to keep details documentation of how your plugin behaves in the
README.md file.Deploying your pluginIf your happy with your plugin: just typenpm version patch
to create a new version, use patch, minor, or major in accordance with semver.
Then to publish to the package registry just type:npm publish
Your plugin will be available in Rinobot.We also recommend you version control your plugin with git and host the repository on github.

tasks/getting_started.html.title: Getting started with tasks
tasks/getting_started.html.body:
Getting started with Rinobot tasks.Rinobot runs tasks for you automatically when data appears in a folder.Choose a folder to monitor and click on 'Setup'.
Choose a command to run from the dropdown list, this list will show the default tasks and all available plugins.
In the 'add file to match' box insert a filename that Rinobot can match to run the task on. For example use '*.txt' to run the task on all txt files. See the article Choosing files to run tasks on for more.
Some tasks require extra information, for example 'rinocloud-upload' will ask you to name a folder on Rinocloud to upload to, and python will require a choice of python script (the same for matlab and R.)
Press 'Start' and Rinobot will start monitoring the folder, when matching files appear, Rinobot will run all the tasks synchronously.
Plugins are the easiest way to use Rinobot to automate processes; but you can do a lot more.Running Python scripts

Running MATLAB scripts

Running R scripts

Running custom commands

tasks/matching_files.html.title: Matching files
tasks/matching_files.html.body:
Choosing files to run tasks onWhen setting up some tasks in Rinobot you must fill out the 'Add file to match' field.
This is how Rinobot chooses whether to run tasks on a certain file or not.So if I set the file to match to be book.txt, then Rinobot would only run on files called
boot.txt, and no more.A * in the filename is a wildcard, representing any name; so *.txt would match all txt files.
The wildcard can be in the middle of a name too, for example: temperature*.txt would match temperature_001.txt but not voltage_001.txt.

tasks/uploading_to_rinocloud.html.title: Uploading to Rinocloud
tasks/uploading_to_rinocloud.html.body:
Uploading to RinocloudNote: soon we will be replacing the simple upload with full synchronisation.Uploading data to Rinocloud is easy with Rinobot, just select the command 'rinocloud-upload',
choose a file match (in the image we use * for everything), and name a folder to upload to.
The Rinocloud folder will be created if it does not already exist.Make sure that uploading is the last task, because if other tasks are converting and processing, we want all the processed data to be uploaded too.

tasks/copying_moving_files.html.title: Copying and moving
tasks/copying_moving_files.html.body:
Copying and movingCopying/moving data is easy, just input the files match for the files you want to copy; and select a destination folder and the files will be copied automatically. Moving is exactly the same.This is very useful when copying files to a network location, for example. Since files get copied when they are created; you wont have to do a bulk copy yourself later.If you want to save the target location of the copied files in the metadata of others files; its easy.Example, copying large files, and saving location in metadata.Imagine an experiment that creates many large images, saved as .tiff files
with are about 200mb each, and the experiment can make 100-200 images per run.
During the course of the experiment a .log file is created which contains a
lot of metadata and parameters of the experiment.We don't want to save the large .tiff files to Rinocloud, since there is too many of them and they are too large for typical data synchronisation; but we definitely want to save the metadata; for sharing and team discussion. What do we do?Automatically copy the large files to an internal network drive, and upload the log files to Rinocloud with metadata attached, and by setting an extra metadata parameter in Rinobot we can make sure the copy target location is saved in metadata as well.We set the target location of the copy/move as metadata in Rinobot: seen in this image

We can reference the metadata parameter in the copy task by inserting the copy location target as {{location}}

Rinobot will run, copy the files, and upload the log files containing metadata and it will contain the copy location

tasks/running_python.html.title: Auto-run python scripts
tasks/running_python.html.body:
Auto-running python with RinobotIf you have some scripts which you already use for processing data, its easy to setup Rinobot to auto-trigger the script on incoming files.Just select python from the command list, choose files to match, and select a python file to run. Currently python 3 is supported by default, but python 2 support is coming soon.Python 3 will be called with the path of the file as an argument; so if you were to run the python script from the command line it would look likepython3 script.py /path/to/file.txt
The file path can be accessed by using the sys library:import sys
filepath = sys.argv[1]
Full example: plotting dataIn this example we make a simple XY line plot of the data in an incoming file, using numpy and matplotlib; there are both included in the Anaconda python distribution which we recommend users install when they install Rinobot.import sys  # so that we can get the filepath
import os  # to split the filepath into name + extension
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def main(filepath):

    # load the data
    data = np.loadtxt(filepath)

    # split into x & y and plot
    x = data[:, 0]
    y = data[:, 1:]
    plt.plot(x, y)

    # save the image as png
    filename_without_ext = os.path.splitext(filepath)[0]
    plt.savefig(filename_without_ext + '.png')


if __name__ == "__main__":
    # call the main function with the filepath
    main(sys.argv[1])
Here we use if __name__ == "__main__": so that we can still use the script in a library as needed.
__name__ will only equal __main__ if the script is called from the command line

tasks/running_matlab.html.title: Auto-run MATLAB scripts

tasks/running_r.html.title: Auto-run R scripts
tasks/running_r.html.body:
Auto-running R with RinobotJust like python and matlab we can auto-run R when files appearJust select Rscript from the command list, choose files to match, and select a R script to run.Rinobot will just execute the following command on the command lineRscript yourscript.R path/to/file.txt
Full example: plotting dataIn this example we make a simple XY line plot of the data in an incoming file. We read the command line arguments into a filepath variable and then plot it.library(tools)
filepath 
So first we get the filepath variable from the command line, then we read the file, and assign it column names, we create an output .png file and we plot.

tasks/running_custom_commands.html.title: Custom commands and batch files
tasks/running_custom_commands.html.body:
Running custom commands and batch files in RinobotIts easy to run any command line task from within Rinobot. Just choose custom
from the dropdown list of commands.Example: (Linux/Mac) run command line programSay we are running a long running simulation, and at the end of the simulation we want to call
a compiled program called process-data and feed it the files created by the simulation:process-data ./simulation/output.txt
We just insert a command like in the image belowExample: (Windows) run batch file programSay we have a simple batch file called script.bat, containing the following code, which prints the arguments passed to itecho %1
So on windows if we typed the following into the console>>> ./script.bat /path/to/file.txt
It would emit>>> /path/to/file.txt
so we can easy pass files to batch files by using the following commandWe need to pass the powershell and /c arguments because Rinobot spawns a new instance of powershell to run the file.With this you can schedule a whole bunch of windows commands to operate on data as it appears.

metadata/.title: Metadata
metadata/.body: MetadataGetting started with metadata in rinobot

metadata/getting_started.html.title: Adding extra metadata
metadata/getting_started.html.body:
Adding extra metadata to files in RinobotIf you want extra metadata to be saved with files uploaded to Rinocloud just go
to the 'Metadata' tab of the file setting and insert any values you wish.You can refer to these values again in the commands, using the notation {{metadata-name}}For example if we want to add the location of some network files to copy we just add a location to the metadataWe can reference the metadata parameter in the copy task by inserting the copy location target as {{location}}This location will then be attached to the metadata of any uploaded files.

introduction/clearing_rinobot_records.ht.title: Clearing Rinobot records
introduction/clearing_rinobot_records.ht.body:
Clearing the record to re-run tasks.When Rinobot runs tasks on files in a directory it keeps a log of the finished
tasks in a folder called .rino/ (the . means that the folder will be hidden in
  explorer or Finder).If you want to re-run tasks you can simply click the 'Clear record' button.Be careful: this can cause a lot of wasted time if you don't actually need to re-run tasks.
